name: 80000 hours
description: This dataset contains the list of global challenges that 80,000 hours lists as the most important to address.

questions.name: Risks from artificial intelligence
questions.description: The development of AI is likely to greatly influence the course we take as a society. We think that if it goes badly, however, it could pose an existential threat.

questions.name: Catastrophic pandemics
questions.description: Biotechnological developments threaten to make much deadlier pandemics possible, due to accidental leaks or malicious use of engineered pathogens.

questions.name: Nuclear war
questions.description: Nuclear weapons were the first genuine man-made existential threat. Despite some progress, we have not reduced the threat of nuclear war enough.

questions.name: Great power war
questions.description: There’s a significant chance that a new great power war occurs this century — and this seems like a major risk factor for existential catastrophe. However, it seems hard to reduce this risk.

questions.name: Climate change
questions.description: Beyond the suffering it’s already causing, worse climate change could increase existential risks from other causes and affect standards of living far into the future.

questions.name: Civilisation resilience
questions.description: If we make it more likely that the world’s population could eventually recover from a catastrophic collapse, we could save the possibility of a flourishing future even if a catastrophe does occur.

questions.name: 'S-risks'
questions.description: Worse than extinction would be a long future of great suffering. The study of these suffering risks (‘s-risks’) aims to specifically minimise the chance of a terrible outcome.

questions.name: Artificial sentience
questions.description: We may soon create machines capable of experiencing happiness and suffering, whose wellbeing will matter just like our own. But our understanding of consciousness is so incomplete, we might not even realise when this becomes possible.

questions.name: Promoting positive values
questions.description: If we could effectively spread positive values — like (we think!) caring about the wellbeing of all sentient beings impartially — that could be one of the broadest ways to help with a range of problems.

questions.name: Risks of stable totalitarianism
questions.description: If a totalitarian regime ever becomes technologically advanced enough and gains enough global control, might it persist more or less indefinitely?

questions.name: Space governance
questions.description: Even as investment in space increases, we have very little plan for how nations, companies, and individuals will interact fairly and peacefully there.

questions.name: Improving incentives and governance for global public goods
questions.description: There are many ‘public goods’ problems, where no one is incentivised to do what would be best for everyone. Can we design mechanisms and institutions to mitigate this issue?

questions.name: Risks from atomically precise manufacturing
questions.description: The ability to manipulate the creation of molecules would plausibly have large impacts and could be crucial in many of the worst — and best — case scenarios for advanced AI.

questions.name: Risks from malevolent actors
questions.description: Some of the worst possible futures might be less likely if we better understood why some people intentionally cause great harm (and how that harm could be limited).

questions.name: Improving individual reasoning and cognition
questions.description: The world’s most pressing problems pose immense intellectual challenges. Better reasoning by researchers and decision-makers could give us a better shot at solving them.

questions.name: Factory farming
questions.description: Every year, billions of animals suffer on factory farms, where standards of humane treatment generally range from low to nonexistent.

questions.name: Global health
questions.description: Preventable diseases like malaria kill hundreds of thousands of people each year. We can improve global healthcare and reduce extreme poverty with more funding and more effective organisations.

questions.name: Whole brain emulation
questions.description: Digitally running specific human brains — ‘mind uploading’ — might be a safer way to get some of the benefits of artificial intelligence, but might also pose its own risks.

questions.name: Wild animal suffering
questions.description: There is an unfathomable number of wild animals. If many of them suffer in their daily lives and if we can find a (safe) way to help them, that would do a lot of good.

questions.name: Safeguarding liberal democracy
questions.description: Liberal democracies seem more conducive to innovation, freedom, and possibly peace. There’s a lot of effort already going into this area, but there may be some ways to add more value.

questions.name: Immigration restrictions
questions.description: Keeping people from moving to where they would have better lives and careers can have big negative humanitarian, intellectual, cultural, and economic effects.

questions.name: Spread of false ideas on social media
questions.description: The algorithms that social media companies employ to curate content may be contributing to harmful instability and erosion of trust in many societies.

questions.name: Science policy and infrastructure
questions.description: Incentives shaped by universities and journals affect scientific progress. Can we improve them, e.g., to speed up development of beneficial technologies (and limit the proliferation of risky ones)?

questions.name: High-leverage ways to speed up economic growth
questions.description: Faster economic growth could improve global standards of living and cooperation, and might help future generations flourish.

questions.name: Mental health
questions.description: Depression, anxiety, and other conditions directly affect people’s wellbeing. Finding effective and scalable ways to improve mental health worldwide could deliver large benefits.
